properties.name: Willowdell Arch
properties.description: This sandstone-and-brick arch stands at the East Drive between the Mall and Fifth Avenue and leads visitors to the bronze statue of Balto, the celebrated Alaskan sled dog.

properties.name: William Tecumseh Sherman
properties.description: The sculpture of General William Tecumseh Sherman is one of the finest sculptures by the talented American sculptor and New York City resident Augustus St.Gaudens.

properties.name: William Shakespeare
properties.description: William Shakespeare was the first sculpture of a writer to be placed on the Mall, known informally as Literary Walk.

properties.name: Wien Walk
properties.description: Wien Walk is one of the most heavily traveled entrance paths into Central Park. at Fifth Avenue and 60th Street. It provides access to the Park for thousands of visitors.

properties.name: Wagner Cove
properties.description: Wagner Cove is one of Central Park's hidden oases of calm. Tucked away into a shady corner of the Lake, the Cove features a small rustic wood shelter.

properties.name: Volleyball Courts
properties.description: Volleyball courts are available for play during warmer weather months.

properties.name: Volleyball
properties.description: Pickup volleyball games can be played year-round at courts on a first-come, first-served basis within Central Park.

properties.name: Victorian Gardens Amusement Park
properties.description: As the summer operation of Wollman Rink, this whimsical family amusement park features twelve hand-crafted rides that are sure to delight all guests.

properties.name: Victor Herbert
properties.description: This bronze portrait bust commemorates the renowned Irish-American composer and conductor. It stands appropriately near the site of his countless memorable performances on the Park's concert ground.

properties.name: Umpire Rock
properties.description: One of the best examples of Central Park's rich endowment of exposed bedrock, Umpire Rock is likely named for its commanding view of nearby baseball diamonds.

properties.name: Trefoil Arch
properties.description: This ornamental archway made of brownstone is unique in that its east and west side walls have distinctly different looks. It is named for its signature feature, the three-lobe patterned arch on its east side.

properties.name: Thomas Moore
properties.description: This bronze bust of the Irish poet stands on the eastern edge of the Pond. Moore was considered the national bard of Ireland in the early 19th century.

properties.name: The Pond
properties.description: The Pond is one of Central Park's seven naturalistic water bodies. When Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux designed Central Park, they imagined an immediate reprieve from the City's streets and designed the Pond as a serene escape, just feet from Fifth Avenue. Despite the millions of visitors who walk by the water's edge each year, you can still find a sense of solitude.

properties.name: The Point
properties.description: The Point is a verdant peninsula in the Ramble that juts into the Lake. It offers visitors a beautiful vantage point from which to view Bethesda Terrace to the south and Bow Bridge to the west.

properties.name: The Pilgrim
properties.description: On the occasion of the New England Society's 75th anniversary, the association commissioned the statue to honor America's earliest colonists.

properties.name: The Mall and Literary Walk
properties.description: The Mall, a quadruple row of American elms, is Central Park's most important horticultural feature, and one of the largest and last remaining stands of American Elm trees in North America.

properties.name: The Lake
properties.description: The 20-acre Lake is the second largest of Central Park's man-made water bodies.

properties.name: The Falconer
properties.description: The sculpture depicts both a human figure, clad in Elizabethan dress, and a falcon, representing the union and communion between a bird of prey and man.

properties.name: Strawberry Fields
properties.description: Strawberry Fields is a living memorial to the world-famous singer, songwriter and peace activist, John Lennon.

properties.name: Sir Walter Scott
properties.description: Walter Scott (1771-1832), author of the popular novel Ivanhoe, is celebrated for his invention of the historical novel.

properties.name: Simon Bolivar
properties.description: Simon Bolivar (1783-1830), born in Venezuela and one of South America's greatest generals, was called El Liberator because his victories over Spaniards won independence for Bolivia.

properties.name: Sheep Meadow
properties.description: Although today the Park's largest lawn without ballfields features people it was originally the home to a flock of pure bred sheep from 1864 until 1934. The sheep and shepherd were housed in a fanciful Victorian building nearby, what became the famous Tavern on the Green restaurant in 1934.

properties.name: Rumsey Playfield
properties.description: Rumsey Playfield â€“ a hot spot for music, dance, spoken word, and film as the home of the popular SummerStage cultural series.

properties.name: Robert Burns
properties.description: Robert Burns (1759-1796), Scotland's national poet, is most famous for his song Auld Lang Syne.

properties.name: Riftstone Arch
properties.description: Arching over the Park's bridle path, Riftstone is built with blocks of Manhattan schist that had been blasted from the Park's rock outcrops.

properties.name: Richard Morris Hunt
properties.description: This striking, curved monument on the Park's eastern perimeter honors Richard Morris Hunt, the most prominent architect of his time.

properties.name: Playmates Arch
properties.description: Playmates Arch, designed by Calvert Vaux in 1863, links the Dairy and the Carousel, and its light-hearted name comes from its position in the Children's District, the area in the southern end of the Park that had many features and amenities dedicated to children.

properties.name: Pilgrim Hill
properties.description: The knoll that rises to the southwest of Conservatory Water is known as Pilgrim Hill because of the bronze statue of a Pilgrim that crowns the crest. It is one of the best sledding spots in the Park.

properties.name: Olmsted Flower Bed
properties.description: The flowerbed at the southern end of the Mall was created in 1972 to commemorate the 150th anniversary of Frederick Law Olmsted's birthday.

properties.name: Nell Singer Lilac Walk
properties.description: On the northern edge of Sheep Meadow, Lilac Walk boasts varieties of its signature fragrant flower from around the world. It is named for philanthropist Nell Singer, who financed its creation in 1970.

properties.name: Naumburg Bandshell
properties.description: At the Naumburg Bandshell on the concert ground at the northern end of the Mall, you might enjoy a variety of organized, unamplified musical events.

properties.name: Mother Goose
properties.description: Here children can see Mother Goose flying her large goose as her cape is blown upward by the wind.

properties.name: Minton Tile Ceiling at Bethesda Terrace
properties.description: Bethesda Terrace arcade was created in the 1860s as a part of the Park's main architectural feature. The highlight of the arcade is the magnificent Minton Tile ceiling.

properties.name: Lombard Lamp
properties.description: A charming touch of old world Germany, the Lombard Lamp illuminates the nook of Central Park where a long, winding staircase leads up from the Pond to the Grand Army Plaza.

properties.name: Loeb Boathouse Refreshments
properties.description: At Loeb Boathouse, visitors can rent rowboats and bikes, hire an authentic Venetian gondola, or dine overlooking views of the Lake.

properties.name: Loeb Boathouse
properties.description: At the Loeb Boathouse, visitors can rent rowboats and bikes, hire an authentic Venetian gondola, or dine overlooking views of the Lake.

properties.name: Lehman Gates
properties.description: Designed by Paul Manship, the sculptor of one of the more elaborate gates at the Wildlife Conservation Center in the Bronx (the Bronx Zoo), the Lehman Gates' animals birds, and boys are interwoven in a fanciful scrolling lintel.

properties.name: Le Pain Quotidien
properties.description: Le Pain Quotidien is the popular European cafe chain that transformed the concession building north of Sheep Meadow at Mineral Springs, serving bakery fare, healthful salads, handmade breads, and organic drinks.

properties.name: Lawn Bowling and Croquet
properties.description: Central Park is home to two beautiful fields for lawn bowling and croquet, each 15,000 square feet.

properties.name: Jose Julian Marti
properties.description: JosÃ© JuliÃ¡n MartÃ­, a Cuban patriot, journalist and poet, fought for the liberation of Cuba from Spanish rule. The statue shows the moment when MartÃ­ was mortally wounded in battle.

properties.name: Jose de San Martin
properties.description: The monument is a smaller-scale replica cast from the original, erected in the Plaza de San Martin in Buenos Aires in 1862. It was a gift from the City of Buenos Aires to the City of New York.

properties.name: Johann C.F. von Schiller
properties.description: German-American citizens wished to honor their country's cultural heroes, Beethoven and Schiller, with monuments in the Park. The bust of Schiller, dramatist, poet, and philosopher, was the first sculpture to be placed in the Park.

properties.name: Inscope Arch
properties.description: Connecting the Zoo with the Pond, Inscope is a striking example of Ruskinian Gothic architecture perfected by Park architect Jacob Wrey Mould.

properties.name: Indian Hunter
properties.description: Indian Hunter was the first sculpture in Central Park created by an American artist, John Quincy Adams Ward.

properties.name: Honey Bear
properties.description: This whimsical bronze statue is part of a pair of niche sculptures that flank the brick triple-archway between the Central Park Zoo and the Children's Zoo.

properties.name: Heckscher Playground
properties.description: When Frederick Law Olmsted and Calvert Vaux designed Central Park in the 19th Century, they designated this 10-acre meadow in the southwest corner of the Park as a "playground" â€” the term used to describe a versatile open meadow intended for games, sports and informal play.

properties.name: Heckscher Ballfields
properties.description: Hundreds of baseball and softball games are played each season at the six fields that make up the newly restored Heckscher Ballfields.

properties.name: Hans Christian Andersen
properties.description: Hans Christian Andersen is one of the most popular climbing sculptures in the Park.

properties.name: Hallett Nature Sanctuary
properties.description: Wrapping around the Pond at the southeast corner of Central Park is the 4-acre Hallett Nature Sanctuary, a peaceful haven just feet away from some of the most heavily trafficked paths of any park in the world.

properties.name: Green Gap Arch
properties.description: Originally serving the bridle path going toward the Scholar's Gate entrance of the Park, Green Gap Arch is now closed and part of the Central Park Zoo.

properties.name: Giuseppe Mazzini
properties.description: Commissioned by an Italian-American group, this bronze bust of the Italian patriot, philosopher, and politician overlooks Sheep Meadow.

properties.name: Gill Rustic Bridge
properties.description: Azalea Pond is fed by a tumbling stream called the Gill, which has its own rustic bridge, complete with benches for admiring the beautiful azalea blooms in the spring.

properties.name: Gapstow Bridge
properties.description: Curving gracefully over the neck of the Pond at 59th Street, Gapstow is one of the iconic bridges of Central Park. It is the second bridge in its place. The first, a much more elaborate wood and iron bridge, designed by Jacob Wrey Mould, deteriorated and was replaced in 1896.

properties.name: Fitz-Greene Halleck
properties.description: The least known literary figure today on the mall, Halleck was a writer of satirical and romantic verse, and for many years the personal secretary to the eminent John Jacob Astor.

properties.name: East Green
properties.description: Visitors in search of a tranquil area to relax on a lawn can head to East Green, one of eight designated Quiet Zones in Central Park.

properties.name: East 72nd Street Playground
properties.description: This playground's low concrete walls and numerous steps and seats define the play space, as well as providing a variety of levels and surfaces to climb and explore.

properties.name: Eagles and Prey
properties.description: This bronze sculpture is well known for the fine detail of the animals' textures â€” in this case the feathers of the eagles and the woolly coat of the goat.

properties.name: Driprock Arch
properties.description: Driprock Arch originally stood over the bridle path that was destroyed with the expansion of Heckscher Playground in the 1930s.

properties.name: Doris C. Freedman Plaza
properties.description: The Doris C. Freedman Plaza is home to rotating installations, courtesy of the city's Public Art Fund.

properties.name: Dipway Arch
properties.description: Set beneath the Park Drive and measuring more than 15 feet wide, Dipway Arch's underpass leads around Heckscher Playground and north toward the Carousel.

properties.name: Denesmouth Arch
properties.description: One of Calvert Vaux's earliest arches, Denesmouth supports the 65th Street Transverse and it is the only Transverse Arch that is highly ornamented.

properties.name: Dene
properties.description: The Dene is a long stretch of eastside landscape that exemplifies both the design features and the intended effect of Olmsted's pastoral vision. It offers gently rolling lawns and shaded walks.

properties.name: Delacorte Clock
properties.description: Named after philanthropist George T. Delacorte, the clock brings seasonal chimes and nursery rhymes on the half hour. It is one of the most popular features in Central Park.

properties.name: Daniel Webster
properties.description: In the 1870s, this larger-than-life-size version of the stateman was comissioned for Central Park. It proved too large for placement on the Mall as originally intended and was subsequently installed on the West Drive.

properties.name: Dancing Goat
properties.description: This whimsical bronze statue is part of a pair of niche sculptures that flank the buildings in the Central Park Zoo.

properties.name: Dancing Crane Cafe
properties.description: Featuring a wide variety of meals, snacks, and beverages for both Park and Zoo visitors. Indoor and outdoor seating.

properties.name: Dalehead Arch
properties.description: Dalehead Arch carries the West Drive over the bridle path that leads westward to the Heckscher Ballfields.

properties.name: Dairy Visitor Center and Gift Shop
properties.description: As one of the Conservancy's five visitor centers, Parkgoers can find information on Park events and programs at the Dairy. Maps, guides, and gifts are also available, all of which support the Conservancy's mission.

properties.name: Cop Cot
properties.description: Cop Cot, which may means "little cottage on the crest of the hill" in Scottish is Central Park's largest wooden rustic structure.

properties.name: Christopher Columbus
properties.description: 1892 was marked by celebrations of the 400th anniversary of Columbus's arrival in the Americas and to commemorate the event, Italians funded the dedication of Gaetano Russo's Columbus Circle stone monument on the perimeter of Central Park. Another statue of Columbus, by Spanish sculptor Jeronimo Sunol was unveiled on May 12, 1894 on the Mall.

properties.name: Chess & Checkers House
properties.description: The Chess & Checkers House is one of five Park visitor centers run by the Central Park Conservancy. Chess and Checkers players are welcome to borrow pieces from the Conservancy staff, or bring their own. Dominos and backgammon are also available.

properties.name: Cherry Hill Fountain
properties.description: This fountain at the crest of Cherry Hill is centered at what was once a scenic turn-around for carriages. This Victorian fountain originally served as a watering trough for horses.

properties.name: Cherry Hill
properties.description: A gentle slope overlooking the Lake with views to the Ramble, Cherry Hill offers a contemplative space perfect for picnicking, reading, and sunbathing.

properties.name: Central Park Zoo
properties.description: Central Park's new, state-of-the-art Zoo was built when the Wildlife Conservation Society took over the management in 1984. It showcases animals from tropical, temperate, and polar zones around the world.

properties.name: Carousel
properties.description: The famed Carousel, with its sweet calliope music and 57 magnificent horses, is the fourth to stand in Central Park since 1871. It is one of Central Park's most popular attractions.

properties.name: Bow Bridge
properties.description: The first cast-iron bridge in the Park (and the second oldest in America), the bridge is named for its graceful shape, reminiscent of the bow of an archer or violinist.

properties.name: Billy Johnson Playground
properties.description: This playground's design was inspired by the landscapes of Central Park, making it one of the Park's most distinctive play spaces.

properties.name: Bicycle Rental
properties.description: Bicycles for riding in Central Park are available for rent at the Loeb Central Park Boathouse daily, April through November.

properties.name: Bethesda Terrace
properties.description: Park designers Olmsted and Vaux envisioned a Promenade that led to a grand terrace overlooking the Lake. The carvings represent the four seasons and, on the side facing the Mall, the times of day.

properties.name: Balto
properties.description: This sculpture honors the sled dog who saved Alaska's children from a diphtheria epidemic by delivering medicine over the frozen tundra.

properties.name: Ballplayers' House Refreshments
properties.description: Enjoy salads, sandwiches, burgers and other ballpark snacks at this eatery on the northern edge of the Heckscher Ballfields.

properties.name: Adventure Playground
properties.description: Short concrete walls enclose the play area of this playground, linking play equipment while also functioning as a maze and seating area.

properties.name: 7th Regiment Memorial
properties.description: This statue honors the 58 men of the 7th Regiment who died defending the Union during the Civil War.

properties.name: 107th United States Infantry
properties.description: One of the several war memorials in Central Park, this monument is dedicated to those soldiers who served and died in World War I.

properties.name: Women's Gate
properties.description: Central Park West at West 72nd Street

properties.name: Scholars's Gate
properties.description: 5th Avenue at East 60th Street

properties.name: Artists's Gate
properties.description: Central Park South at 6th Avenue
